sense.name: emotional reaction, affective awareness
sense.commentary: FEELING[+state][+mental][+reaction][+emotional] Note: focus is on emotional reaction, rather than belief or rational opinion. (Sense 2)
sense.examples: Through therapy she learned to recognize her hostile feelings and reason through them. Bob dislikes Trudy and the feeling is apparently mutual. He had trouble overcoming his feelings of inadequacy. Their society has a collective feeling of guilt about past transgressions. (group extension) She spoke with great feeling at the memorial service. The children tried to express their feelings through pictures. John had a sinking feeling when he saw Mary's face.

sense.name: a general impression, belief or sense about something
sense.commentary: FEELING[+state][+mental][+impression][+sense/+belief] Note: focus is on intuition, beliefs rather than emotion (see Sense 1)
sense.examples: He had a feeling he was being watched. What is Wall Street's feeling about the weakening dollar? Did you get the feeling he was lying about it? John had a bad feeling about the business venture.

sense.name: the atmosphere or ambience surrounding something
sense.commentary: FEELING[+quality][+atmosphere][+mood] Note: the feeling is not attributed to an individual, but is presented as a general condition
sense.examples: There was a feeling of excitement in the air. The committee meeting had the feeling of a well-rehearsed charade to Pete. The mayor tried to dispel the town's feeling of despair after the disaster. The young photographer loved the feeling of energy in the big city.

sense.name: experiencing a physical sensation
sense.commentary: FEELING[+state][+physical][+sensation][+tingling/+burning/+lacking] Note: implies an individual who experiences the sensation
sense.examples: The patient reported a loss of feeling in his left hand. John had a queasy feeling in his stomach from the pitching boat. She experienced a burning feeling in her right foot.

sense.name: the tactile (touch) quality something has
sense.commentary: FEELING[+quality][+tactile][+smooth/+greasy/+cool/+hard/+silky] Note: refers to an inherent quality of a thing, not the person experiencing it (see Sense 4)
sense.examples: The surface of it had a greasy feeling. This fabric has too rough of a feeling to be comfortable next to the skin. The feeling of this papaya's skin is smooth.

sense.name: having an intuitive understanding or appreciation of something
sense.commentary: FEELING[+quality][+ability][+intuitive][+understanding] Note: refers to an inherent ability or faculty
sense.examples: The child prodigy had a real feeling for Beethoven's violin sonatas. John seems to have little feeling for art. Through practice you will develop a better feeling for how to trim your sails according to the direction of the wind.

sense.name: emotional or moral sensitivity
sense.commentary: FEELINGS[+quality][+emotional][+sensitivity][+identity][+personal] Note: occurs in the plural Note: a very narrow usage of Sense 1, refers to one's sense of identity
sense.examples: The teasing remarks of his classmates hurt the boy's feelings. The scene at the leather bar shocked Betty's feelings of propriety and modesty. THe boss was a bully who tended to trample on everyone's feelings.
